div.p: Your letter to my father-in-law, Mr. Benedict Stocker, concerning a French scholarship holder and his payment, was received and discussed by my mother-in-law in the absence of my father-in-law, and she instructed me to write to you the following opinion: namely, that although according to your letter my father-in-law has been in France for some time, he has not been able to find out where or in which place Coignet is currently staying.
She also does not know whether Coignet has written anything to my father-in-law about this matter or not.
However, she intends to give your letter to my father-in-law when he returns home, or in case it is not known when he will return, to send it to him these days.
In good hope, you will find good information and money with him, etc.
Which she should not withhold from you as a friendly response at this time.
I am willing to serve you.
Given in Schaffhausen on the 28th of September in the year 1563.
Your willing Hans im Thurn of Schaffhausen.
To the honorable well-learned Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, master of the liberal arts and preacher in Zurich, my dear sir.
